New Records: Freddy Peralta pitched six scoreless innings, allowing only two hits and three walks, striking out eight.
William Contreras capped a five-run fifth inning with a two-run home run, his 18th of the season.
Key Match Events: Peralta's six scoreless innings kept the Giants off the board until the sixth inning.
Contreras' two-run home run in the fifth inning started the scoring and ended any chance of a Giants comeback.
The Brewers scored five runs in the fifth inning, including a two-run double by Blake Perkins and Contreras' home run.
Devin Williams recorded his sixth save in seven chances after a mound visit.
The Giants scored three runs in the seventh and eighth innings, but the Brewers held on for the win.
Post-Match Reflections: Milwaukee Brewers manager Pat Murphy praised Peralta's performance and the team's resilience.
San Francisco Giants manager Bob Melvin noted that the Brewers' five-run fifth inning deflated his team, but they managed to comeback.
Peralta expressed relief after striking out the final batter, ending a streak of lower strikeouts.
Contreras highlighted Peralta's execution and zone attack as key factors in the win.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Giants had a 9-1 record in their last 14 games dating back to 2019.
Patrick Bailey, the Giants' catcher, was on the injured list with a right oblique strain and could be activated soon.
The Brewers moved closer to the NL playoffs, within 1.5 games of the Philadelphia Phillies for the second seed.
